markdownRemark.excerpt: This is the first post of the Introduction to Abstract Algebra series. In the first post, we introduce the basic concepts in abstract algebra, starting from…
markdownRemark.html:
This is the first post of the Introduction to Abstract Algebra series. In the first post, we introduce the basic concepts in abstract algebra, starting from mappings, equivalent relations, partitions, and extending to groups and homomorphisms. We will also encounter an important theorem: the Lagrange’s theorem.

  • Preliminaries
  • Groups
  • Homomorphisms and Isomorphisms
  • The Lagrange’s Theorem
  • References

Preliminaries

Definition 1.1: Cartesian Product

  • For two sets AAA and BBB, there Cartesian product is A×B={(a,b)∣a∈A,b∈B}A \times B = \{(a, b) \mid a \in A, b \in B\}A×B={(a,b)∣a∈A,b∈B}.

Definition 1.2: Mapping

  • A mapping fff from the set AAA to the set BBB, denotes has f:A→Bf: A \to Bf:A→B, is an unambiguous association of an element in AAA to an element in BBB. Note that f⊆A×Bf \subseteq A \times Bf⊆A×B.
  • AAA is the domain of fff, BBB is the codomain of fff, f(A)={f(a)∣a∈A}f(A) = \{f(a) \mid a \in A\}f(A)={f(a)∣a∈A} is the image/range of fff.
  • fff is onto/surjective if f(A)=Bf(A) = Bf(A)=B.
  • fff is injective if ∀a1,a2∈A,a1≠a2,f(a1)  ⟹  f(a1)≠f(a2)\forall a_1, a_2 \in A, a_1 \neq a_2, f(a_1) \implies f(a_1) \neq f(a_2)∀a1​,a2​∈A,a1​=a2​,f(a1​)⟹f(a1​)=f(a2​).
  • fff is bijective if fff is surjective and injective.

Definition 1.3: Equivalence Relation

  • Given a set AAA, a relation RRR is a subset of A×AA \times AA×A, i.e., R⊆A×AR \subseteq A \times AR⊆A×A. For a1,a2∈Aa_1, a_2 \in Aa1​,a2​∈A, if (a1,a2)∈R(a_1, a_2) \in R(a1​,a2​)∈R, put a1∼a2a_1 \sim a_2a1​∼a2​.

  • RRR is is an equivalence relation if:

    1. (reflexivity) a∼a,∀a∈Aa \sim a, \forall a \in Aa∼a,∀a∈A.
    2. (symmetry) a∼b  ⟹  b∼a,∀a,b∈Aa \sim b \implies b \sim a, \forall a, b \in Aa∼b⟹b∼a,∀a,b∈A.
    3. (transitivity) a∼b,b∼c  ⟹  a∼c,∀a,b,c∈Aa \sim b, b \sim c \implies a \sim c, \forall a, b, c \in Aa∼b,b∼c⟹a∼c,∀a,b,c∈A.
  • For a set AAA and an equivalence relation ∼\sim∼ on AAA, [a]={x∈A∣x∼a}[a] = \{x \in A \mid x \sim a\}[a]={x∈A∣x∼a} is an equivalence class. We define A/∼A/\simA/∼ as the set of equivalence classes.

Example 1.1: Set Z/nZ\mathbb Z/n\mathbb ZZ/nZ

An equivalence relation on Z\mathbb ZZ is R={(a,b)∣a,b∈Z,a≡bmod  n}R = \{(a, b) \mid a, b \in \mathbb Z, a \equiv b \mod n\}R={(a,b)∣a,b∈Z,a≡bmodn}. This relation is called congruence modulo nnn. The n−1n-1n−1 equivalence classes induced by congruence modulo nnn, also referred to as congruence classes, form a set called Z/nZ\mathbb Z/ n \mathbb ZZ/nZ. For example, Z/2Z\mathbb Z/ 2 \mathbb ZZ/2Z contains two congruence classess: [0][0][0] and [1][1][1].

Definition 1.4: Paritition

  • Given a set AAA, a partition is a set of non-empty subsets Ai⊆AA_i \subseteq AAi​⊆A such that:

    1. ∪iAi=A\cup_i A_i = A∪i​Ai​=A
    2. For i≠ji \neq ji=j, Ai∩Aj =∅A_i \cap A_j \ = \emptysetAi​∩Aj​ =∅
  • Lemma: An equivalence relation A/∼A/\simA/∼ on AAA is a partition of AAA.

Groups

A group is a set and a binary operation. Intuitively, a group is simply some elements and a rule that describes how they interact.

Definition 1.5: Group

  • A group is a (G,∘)(G, \circ)(G,∘) is a set GGG and a binary operation ∘:G×G→G\circ: G \times G \to G∘:G×G→G that satisfies the following axioms:

    1. (associativity) (a∘b)∘c=a∘(b∘c),∀a,b,c∈G(a \circ b) \circ c = a \circ (b \circ c), \forall a, b, c \in G(a∘b)∘c=a∘(b∘c),∀a,b,c∈G.
    2. (identity) There exists an identity element e∈Ge \in Ge∈G such that e∘a=a∘e=a,∀a∈Ge \circ a = a \circ e = a, \forall a \in Ge∘a=a∘e=a,∀a∈G.
    3. (inverse) For each element a∈Ga \in Ga∈G, there exists an inverse a−1∈Ga^{-1} \in Ga−1∈G such that a∘a−1=ea \circ a^{-1} = ea∘a−1=e. An equivalent statement of the three axioms is that a group is closed under multiplication and inverses. When the meaning is unambiguous, we often drop the binary operation and simply refers the group as GGG.

Applying the three axioms, we can easily show several useful properties below.

Properties 1.6: Basic Properties of a Group

  • Given a group GGG:

    1. The identity element is unique.x
    2. Every element has a unique inverse.
    3. If a∘b=ea \circ b = ea∘b=e, then b∘a=eb \circ a = eb∘a=e.
    4. (a∘b)−1=b−1∘a−1(a \circ b)^{-1} = b^{-1} \circ a^{-1}(a∘b)−1=b−1∘a−1.
    5. a−1−1=ea^{-1^{-1}} = ea−1−1=e.

Definition 1.7: Abelian Group A (G,∘)(G, \circ)(G,∘) is abelian if there for every two elements a,b∈Ga, b \in Ga,b∈G, a∘b=b∘aa \circ b = b \circ aa∘b=b∘a.

Definition 1.8: Order Given a group GGG and a element g∈Gg \in Gg∈G, the order of ggg, denoted as ord(g)ord(g)ord(g) or ∣g∣|g|∣g∣, is the smallest k∈Z≥1k \in \mathbb Z_{\geq 1}k∈Z≥1​ such that gk=eg^k = egk=e and gi≠eg^i \neq egi=e for i<ki < ki<k, where gkg^kgk here means applying the binary operation on kkk copies of ggg. If such a kkk does not exist, we say ggg has infinite order.

Note that we also talk about the order of an group, which is the size of the underlying set.

Definition 1.9: Cyclic Group A group GGG is cyclic if there exists a g∈Gg \in Gg∈G such that G={gk∣k∈Z}G = \{g^k \mid k \in \mathbb Z\}G={gk∣k∈Z}. We call ggg the generator of GGG. We say ggg generates GGG and write G=⟨g⟩G = \langle g \rangleG=⟨g⟩. Obviously, ord(g)=∣G∣ord(g) = |G|ord(g)=∣G∣.

Property 1.10: Properties of Cyclic Groups

Let GGG be a finite cyclic group, G=⟨x⟩G = \langle x \rangleG=⟨x⟩ and ∣G∣=n|G| = n∣G∣=n. Then,

  1. For a positive integer kkk, ∣xk∣=n/gcd(n,k)|x^k| = n/gcd(n,k)∣xk∣=n/gcd(n,k). This implies that the generators of GGG has an order coprime with nnn, so the number of generators of GGG is ϕ(n)\phi(n)ϕ(n), where again ϕ(n)\phi(n)ϕ(n) is the Euler’s totient function.
  2. Every subgroup of GGG is cyclic. Suppose HHH is a subgroup of GGG, and am∈Ha^m \in Ham∈H is the element of smallest mmm in HHH. Then for some an∈H,an=aqm+ra^n \in H, a^n = a^{qm+r}an∈H,an=aqm+r for some integers q,r∈Z,r≤mq, r\in \mathbb Z, r \leq mq,r∈Z,r≤m. Then ar=a−qm+n∈Ha^r = a^{-qm+n} \in Har=a−qm+n∈H, but mmm is the smallest order, so r≥mr \geq mr≥m. Thus, r=mr=mr=m, and an=aqma^n = a^{qm}an=aqm, which means H=⟨am⟩H = \langle a^m \rangleH=⟨am⟩.
  3. For a positive integer kkk, if k∣nk \mid nk∣n, there exists a subgroup of GGG of order kkk which is ⟨xn/k⟩\langle x^{n/k} \rangle⟨xn/k⟩.
  4. For a positive integer kkk, ⟨xk⟩=⟨xgcd(n,k)⟩\langle x^{k} \rangle = \langle x^{gcd(n,k)} \rangle⟨xk⟩=⟨xgcd(n,k)⟩.

We will define several important groups.

Example 1.2: Group Z/nZ\mathbb Z/n\mathbb ZZ/nZ

Recall from Example 1.1 that Z/nZ\mathbb Z/n \mathbb ZZ/nZ is a set of congruence classes modulo nnn. We will introduce the group (Z/nZ,+)(\mathbb Z/n \mathbb Z, +)(Z/nZ,+). We define the binary operation +++ for two congruent classes as: [a]+[b]=[a+b][a]+[b] = [a+b][a]+[b]=[a+b], where the latter ”+” is our usual addition on numbers.

P.S. But to be more precise, the latter ”+” is not all separated form our new definitions. When n=0n=0n=0, we get back a group that is isomorphic (for now understand it as equivalent) to Z\mathbb ZZ of integers.

You can check that this binary option is well-defined (unambiguous) and satisfies the above-mentioned axioms. For example, the identity element is clearly [0][0][0]. Also, Z/nZ\mathbb Z/n \mathbb ZZ/nZ is cyclic, and [1][1][1] is its generator.

Example 1.3: Group (Z/nZ)×(\mathbb Z/n\mathbb Z)^\times(Z/nZ)×

First, we define the set (Z/nZ)×={[a]∈Z/nZ∣gcd(a,n)=1}(\mathbb Z/n\mathbb Z)^\times = \{[a] \in \mathbb Z/n\mathbb Z \mid gcd(a,n)=1\}(Z/nZ)×={[a]∈Z/nZ∣gcd(a,n)=1}. In other words, (Z/nZ)×(\mathbb Z/n\mathbb Z)^\times(Z/nZ)× contains the congruent classes that are coprime with nnn. We define the binary operation ×\times× as: [a]×[b]=[a×b][a] \times [b] = [a \times b][a]×[b]=[a×b], where the latter ”×\times×” is our usual multiplication on numbers. It’s less trivial to show that ((Z/nZ)×,×)((\mathbb Z/n\mathbb Z)^\times, \times)((Z/nZ)×,×) is a group.

Property 1.11: The Euclidean Algorithm

Given a,b∈Z,∃x,y∈Za, b \in \mathbb Z, \exists x, y \in \mathbb Za,b∈Z,∃x,y∈Z, such that xa+yb=gcd(a,b)xa + yb = gcd(a,b)xa+yb=gcd(a,b).

ProofProofProof. This can be proven by the Euclidean algorithm.

Lemma 1.12: Group (Z/nZ)×(\mathbb Z/n\mathbb Z)^\times(Z/nZ)×

ProofProofProof. It is straightforward to show that (Z/nZ)×(\mathbb Z/n\mathbb Z)^\times(Z/nZ)× has the identity [1][1][1] and satisfies associativity. We will show every element in (Z/nZ)×(\mathbb Z/n\mathbb Z)^\times(Z/nZ)× has an inverse by Property 1.8.

For a [k]∈(Z/nZ)×,gcd(k,n)=1[k] \in (\mathbb Z/n\mathbb Z)^\times, gcd(k, n) = 1[k]∈(Z/nZ)×,gcd(k,n)=1, so there exists x,y∈Zx, y \in \mathbb Zx,y∈Z such that xk+yn=gcd(k,n)=1xk + yn = gcd(k,n) = 1xk+yn=gcd(k,n)=1, or [x]×[k]=[1][x] \times [k] = [1][x]×[k]=[1]. So [x]=[k]−1[x] = [k]^{-1}[x]=[k]−1. Note that ∣(Z/nZ)×∣=ϕ(n)|(\mathbb Z/n\mathbb Z)^\times| = \phi(n)∣(Z/nZ)×∣=ϕ(n), where ϕ\phiϕ is the Euler’s totient function, which counts numbers lesser than nnn that are coprime with nnn.

We will introduce other important groups like Sn,An,D2n,CnS_n, A_n, D_{2n}, C_nSn​,An​,D2n​,Cn​ later.

Homomorphisms and Isomorphisms

Homomorphisms are mappings from groups to groups.

Definition 1.13: Homomorphism

A homomorphism from a group (G1,∘1)(G_1, \circ_1)(G1​,∘1​) to a group (G2,∘2)(G_2, \circ_2)(G2​,∘2​) is a map ϕ:G1→G2\phi: G_1 \to G_2ϕ:G1​→G2​ such that ϕ(a∘1b)=ϕ(a)∘2ϕ(b)\phi(a \circ_1 b) = \phi(a) \circ_2 \phi(b)ϕ(a∘1​b)=ϕ(a)∘2​ϕ(b).

ProofProofProof. By directly applying the definition of homomorphisms, we can show the following properties.

Property 1.14: Properties of Homomorphisms

Given a homomorphism ϕ:G1→G2\phi: G_1 \to G_2ϕ:G1​→G2​,

  1. ϕ\phiϕ must send e1∈G1e_1 \in G_1e1​∈G1​ to e2∈G2e_2 \in G_2e2​∈G2​, where e1,e2e_1, e_2e1​,e2​ are identities.
  2. ϕ(a−1)\phi(a^{-1})ϕ(a−1) = ϕ(a)−1\phi(a)^{-1}ϕ(a)−1

Definition 1.15: Isomorphisms

An isomorphism from a group (G1,∘1)(G_1, \circ_1)(G1​,∘1​) to a group (G2,∘2)(G_2, \circ_2)(G2​,∘2​) is a bijective homomorphism ϕ:G1→G2\phi: G_1 \to G_2ϕ:G1​→G2​. We say G1G_1G1​ and G2G_2G2​ are isomorphic, denoted as G1≅G2G_1 \cong G_2G1​≅G2​.

Property 1.16: Properties of Isomorphisms

Given an isomorphism ϕ:G1→G2\phi: G_1 \to G_2ϕ:G1​→G2​,

  1. |G1| = |G2|.
  2. G1 is cyclic  ⟺  G2 is cyclicG_1 \text{ is cyclic} \iff G_2 \text{ is cyclic}G1​ is cyclic⟺G2​ is cyclic.
  3. G1 is abelian  ⟺  G2 is abelianG_1 \text{ is abelian} \iff G_2 \text{ is abelian}G1​ is abelian⟺G2​ is abelian.
  4. If g1∈G1g_1 \in G_1g1​∈G1​ has order kkk, ord(ϕ(g1))=kord(\phi(g_1)) = kord(ϕ(g1​))=k.

Moreover,

  1. Any two cyclic groups of the same order are isomorphic. Just send the generator of one group to the generator of the other group.

The Lagrange’s Theorem

Definition 1.17: Subgroup Given a group (G,∘)(G, \circ)(G,∘), (H,∘)(H, \circ)(H,∘) is a subgroup of (G,∘)(G, \circ)(G,∘) if (H,∘)(H, \circ)(H,∘) is a well-defined group and H⊆GH \subseteq GH⊆G is a subset. {e}\{e\}{e} and GGG are trivial subgroups of GGG, where {e}\{e\}{e} is the identity. Again, we simply say HHH is a subgroup of GGG when there are no confusions on the binary operator.

Theorem 1.18: The Lagrange’s theorem

If GGG is a finite group, and H⊂GH \subset GH⊂G is a subgroup. Then ∣H∣∣∣G∣|H| \mid |G|∣H∣∣∣G∣.

Corollary: If GGG is a finite group, and a∈Ga \in Ga∈G. Then ord(a)∣∣G∣ord(a) \mid |G|ord(a)∣∣G∣. This is by observing that aaa generates a subgroup H=⟨a⟩H = \langle a \rangleH=⟨a⟩ which is of size ord(a)ord(a)ord(a).

Corollary 1.19: The Fermat’s little theorem

If ppp is a prime integer, aaa is any integer, then ap≡amod  pa^p \equiv a \mod pap≡amodp.

ProofProofProof. We prove the Fermat’s little theorem by applying Lagrange’s Theorem to (Z/pZ)×(\mathbb Z/p\mathbb Z)^\times(Z/pZ)×, where ppp is a prime. We have that ∣(Z/pZ)×∣=p−1|(\mathbb Z/p\mathbb Z)^\times| = p-1∣(Z/pZ)×∣=p−1, so by the Lagrange’s Theorem, for [a]∈(Z/pZ)×,ord([a])∣p−1[a] \in (\mathbb Z/p\mathbb Z)^\times, ord([a]) \mid p-1[a]∈(Z/pZ)×,ord([a])∣p−1. Thus, we have [a]p−1=[1]  ⟹  [a]p=[a][a]^{p-1} = [1] \implies [a]^{p} = [a][a]p−1=[1]⟹[a]p=[a], or ap≡amod  pa^p \equiv a \mod pap≡amodp.

Corollary: In general, for n∈Z≥1,[a]∈(Z/nZ)×,[a]ϕ(n)=[1]n \in \mathbb Z_{\geq 1}, [a] \in (\mathbb Z/n\mathbb Z)^\times, [a]^{\phi(n)} = [1]n∈Z≥1​,[a]∈(Z/nZ)×,[a]ϕ(n)=[1].

Corollary 1.20: Prime Order Groups Are Cyclic

ProofProofProof. Given a group GGG of order ppp, where ppp is a prime, for an a∈Ga \in Ga∈G, ord(a)∣pord(a) \mid pord(a)∣p, so ord(a)=1 or pord(a) = 1 \text{ or } pord(a)=1 or p. Since the identity is unique, we have p−1p-1p−1 generators.

Now we will prove the Lagrange’s theorem by defining cosets.

Definition 1.21: Coset

Given a group G,H⊂GG, H \subset GG,H⊂G is a subgroup. Define an equivalence relation on GGG by ∀g1,g2∈G,g1∼g2  ⟺  g1H=g2H\forall g_1, g_2 \in G, g_1 \sim g_2 \iff g_1H = g_2H∀g1​,g2​∈G,g1​∼g2​⟺g1​H=g2​H. Here for g∈G,gH={gh∣h∈H}g \in G, gH = \{gh \mid h \in H\}g∈G,gH={gh∣h∈H}. We call gHgHgH a left coset of GGG. Then G/∼G/\simG/∼ is the set of the equivalence classes, or the set of the left cosets. (Similarly, HgHgHg is a right coset).

ProofProofProof. By straightforwardly showing ∼\sim∼ is indeed an equivalence relation, we already have that G/∼G/\simG/∼, or the set of cosets, is a partition of GGG. But to make the idea more transparent, we will show this directly.

  1. We first note that every g∈Gg \in Gg∈G lies in some left coset. Namely, g∈gHg \in gHg∈gH.
  2. We then note that g1H=g2H  ⟺  g2−1g1H=H  ⟺  g2−1g1∈H  ⟺  g2−1g1=h for some h∈H  ⟺  g1=g2hg_1H = g_2H \iff g_2^{-1}g_1 H = H \iff g_2^{-1}g_1 \in H \iff g_2^{-1}g_1 = h \text{ for some } h \in H \iff g_1 = g_2 hg1​H=g2​H⟺g2−1​g1​H=H⟺g2−1​g1​∈H⟺g2−1​g1​=h for some h∈H⟺g1​=g2​h. The second   ⟺  \iff⟺ can be shown by assuming that g2−1g1∉Gg_2^{-1}g_1 \notin Gg2−1​g1​∈/G and noting that g2−1g1∘e=g2−1g1∉G  ⟹  g2−1g1H≠Hg_2^{-1}g_1 \circ e = g_2^{-1}g_1 \notin G \implies g_2^{-1}g_1H \neq Hg2−1​g1​∘e=g2−1​g1​∈/G⟹g2−1​g1​H=H, a contradiction. This easy to prove property, gH=H  ⟺  g∈HgH = H \iff g \in HgH=H⟺g∈H, is a very useful property. Thus, if two left cosets g1Hg_1Hg1​H intersects with g2Hg_2Hg2​H at some element g3g_3g3​, then g1H=g3Hg_1H = g_3Hg1​H=g3​H and g2H=g3Hg_2H = g_3Hg2​H=g3​H, so g1H=g2Hg_1H = g_2Hg1​H=g2​H and they are the same left coset.

ProofProofProof. Finally, we prove the Lagrange’s theorem by defining an isomorphism. Given a group GGG, a subgroup H⊆GH \subseteq GH⊆G and any g∈Gg \in Gg∈G, define the mapping ϕ:H→gH\phi: H \to gHϕ:H→gH as ϕ(h)=gh\phi(h) = ghϕ(h)=gh. The mapping is clearly well-defined. It is injective since gh1=gh2  ⟺  h1=h2gh_1 = gh_2 \iff h_1 = h_2gh1​=gh2​⟺h1​=h2​. It is surjective since by definition, every element of gHgHgH is ghghgh for some h∈Hh \in Hh∈H. Since H≅gHH \cong gHH≅gH, ∣H∣=∣gH∣|H| = |gH|∣H∣=∣gH∣. Thus we show that every left coset has the same cardinality as HHH. Since G/∼G/\simG/∼, the set of left cosets, is a partition of GGG, we have that ∣H∣∣∣G∣|H| \mid |G|∣H∣∣∣G∣.

Definition 1.22: Index

Given a group G,H⊂GG, H \subset GG,H⊂G is a subgroup, ∣G∣/∣H∣|G|/|H|∣G∣/∣H∣, the number of left cosets, is the index of HHH in GGG, denoted as [G:H][G:H][G:H].

References

[1] Siegel, Kyler. MATH GU4041 Introduction to Modern Algebra I. Department of Mathematics, Columbia University. 2019.

[2] Dummit, David and Foote, Richard. Abstract Algebra. Third Edition. John Wiley and Sons, Inc. 2004.

frontmatter.title: Abstract Algebra 01 - The Introduction of Groups
frontmatter.description: This is the first post of the Introduction to Abstract Algebra series, and we will start with groups. In this very first post, we will introduce the basic concepts in group theory, starting from mappings, equivalent relations, partitions, and extending to groups and homomorphisms. We will also encounter the first important theorem, the Lagrange's theorem.
